text: This is a download from BBC Learning English to find out more, visit our website.
6-Mate English from BBCLearningEnglish.com
Hello, this is 6-Mini English from BBC Learning English. I'm Neil.
And I’m Georgina.
speaker: Georgina

text: Gordon Amedian.
Melee Cupfeat on Metinet.
I beg your pardon, Neil.
It's something stuck in your throat.
Are you speaking a foreign language?
Ha, well, actually Georgina, I was saying good morning, please to meet you in English.
But not the English you and I speak.
That was Anglo-Saxon or Old English.
The earliest form of English spoken in the Middle Ages, so between the 5th and 15th century.
It doesn’t sound anything like the way people talk nowadays.
speaker: Georgina

text: No, but it's surprising how many of the words we use today have survived from Old English.
Beer, wine, drink, fish, bread, butter, eye, ear, mouth, head, hand, foot,
life, love, laughter, mother, daughter, sister, brother, son, father,
all Anglo-Saxon words.
Wow, so many everyday words.
But what about the classics Latin and Greek?
I thought a lot of English vocabulary came from there.
That's also true.
But the history of English is the history of invasions.
That’s also true, but the history of English is the history of invasions – you know, when the army of one country fights to enter and control another country.
speaker: invasions

text: Like the Roman invasion of Britain?
speaker: Georgina

text: Right. And later invasions too, by Norse speaking Vikings and Germanic Saxons.
In fact, Georgina, that reminds me of my quiz question.
Go on then, but in modern English if you don’t mind…
speaker: Georgina

text: Okay, well, the year 1066 is remembered for a famous battle.
When the French-speaking Norman King, William the Conqueror, invaded England.
But what is the name of the famous battle?
a) The Battle of Waterloo?,
speaker: Neil

text: b) The Battle of Hastings?, or,
speaker: Neil

text: c) The Battle of Trafalgar?
speaker: Neil

text: Mmm, my history is not great now, but I think it's B, the Battle of Hastings.
Okay, Georgina will find out later another old English word there.
But it's not just words that survive from Anglo-Saxon.
It's word endings too.
The suffix, or letters added to the end of a word, to modify its meaning.
Right, like adding S to make something plural,
as in one bird, two birds, or the nest in goodness and happiness and
Dom as in freedom and kingdom.
Poet Michael Rosen is fascinated by Old English.
Here he is talking about word suffixes to Oxford University Professor Andy Orchard
for BBC Radio 4's programme Word of Mouth.
Listen out for the proportion of modern English that comes from Anglo-Saxon.
speaker: Georgina

text: I walked that, walked a bit on the end.
Yeah, the E.D. ending, most modern verbs, if we would say, you know, I texted my daughter.
I mean, text is obviously comes from Latin.
I tweeted.
We still laps to the Anglo-Saxon.
And generally, when I'm speaking, just let's do it in mathematical terms.
What proportion can we say is Old English?
Can we say like about 80% in common parlance,
sorry to use a French word there?
In speech, it will be something like that,
in the written language less.
So the basic building blocks of who we are and what we think.
Professor Orchard estimates that 80% have spoken English in common parlance comes from Anglo-Saxon.
In common parlance means the words and vocabulary that most people use in ordinary,
everyday conversation.
So Anglo-Saxon words are the building blocks of English.
The basic parts are put together to make something.
He also thinks that the languages we speak shape the way we see the world.
speaker: Neil

text: Here’s Michael Rosen and Professor Andy Orchard discussing this idea on BBC Radio 4 programme, Word of Mouth:
speaker: Georgina

text: Word of Math.
Can we say that English speakers today, as I'm speaking to you now,
Can we say that English speakers today, as I’m speaking to you now, view the world through Anglo-Saxon eyes, through Anglo-Saxon words? Can we say that?
speaker: through Anglo-Saxon eyes

text: Well, certainly in Old English poetry, it's always raining and I suppose it's always raining today.
There is a retrospective element that we're still inhabiting that worldview,
those ideas, the same words, the same simple ideas that they inhabited.
And what's extraordinary if you think about the history of English is despite the
invasions by the Norse and by the Normand, and then despite the years of empire where we're bringing
things back, the English that we're speaking today is still at its root, Old English word,
at its heart, Old English word, still very much English.
Michael Rosen asks if English speakers see the world through Anglo-Saxon eyes.
Michael Rosen asks if English speakers see the world through Anglo-Saxon eyes. When we see something through someone’s eyes, we see it from their perspective, their point of view.
speaker: throughAnglo-Saxon eyesthrough someone’s eyes

text: And Professor Orchard replies by saying that despite all the history of invasion and empire,

And Professor Orchard replies by saying that despite all the history of invasion and empire, the English we speak today is still Old English at heart – a phrase used to say what something is really like.
speaker: at heart

text: Wow! So much history crammed into six minutes! And now, time for one more history fact.
speaker: Neil

text: Do you mean your quiz question, Neil? What’s the name of the famous battle of 1066?
speaker: Georgina

text: What did you say, Georgina?
speaker: Neil

text: I said be the Battle of Hastings.
Which was… the correct answer! The Battle of Hastings in 1066 played a big part in the Norman Conquest and mixing French words into the language.
speaker: Neil

text: Conquest and mixing French words into the language.
And I also know how the English ruler, King Harold, died – shot through the eye with an arrow!
speaker: Georgina

text: Ouch. Okay, let's recap the vocabulary, some of which exists because of invasions,
when one country enters and controls another.
A suffix is added to the end of a word to make a new word.
speaker: suffix

text: The phrase in common parlance means using ordinary, everyday words.
speaker: in common parlance

text: Building blocks are the basic parts used to make something.
speaker: Building blocks

text: To see things through someone’s eyes means, from their point of view.
speaker: through someone’s eyes

text: And finally, at heart is used to say what something is really like.
speaker: at heart

text: That's all for this program. Join us again soon at six minute English, but for now.
Fargazand, that's Old English for goodbye. Fargazand.
